page.title: 04NATURE IN THEDDINGWORTH
page.content: Large numbers of rabbits, many with myxomatosis, inhabit the slopes along the north of our block and the old railway embankment. There are foxes and badgers. The canal, now used for pleasure and coarse fishing, is home to waterhens and mallard, visiting swans and Canada geese. Black headed gulls and herons can be seen. Plants include jewelweed, water forgetmenot, giant waterdock, lady smocks and marsh marigold. Birds include owls and 3 species of woodpecker and immigrant warblers. Sparrows, starlings, dunnocks, robins, blackbirds, tits, swallows and magpies visit gardens. Sunny days bring meadow brown, gatekeeper, common blue, skipper, small heath and peacock butterflies. 150 species of wild flowers grow in the 3 churchyards.
